did.unittitle: Edward M. Rosen collection of FLOWTRAN documentation

bioghist.p: FLOWTRAN is a system of digital computer programs for the mathematical solution of steady-state chemical engineering problems. The purpose of FLOWTRAN is to enable design, process and production engineers to make use of powerful, up-to-date, chemical engineering calculating tools in their day-to-day work. FLOWTRAN was released within Monsanto in 1966. Edward M. Rosen joined Monsanto in 1959, where he worked with an early IBM computer and a FORTRAN compiler on a material balance program, and then in the field of computerized simulation of chemical processes. Alvin Larsen (d. 2004) joined Monsanto in 1969, and was a co-worker of Rosen's. He carefully collected manuals and other documentation about FLOWTRAN. This collection is made up of his records, those of Rosen, and those of a few others.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of manuals, reports, internal Monsanto memos and correspondence relating to Monsanto's FLOWTRAN system. Records include: FORTRAN listings of the internal and external FLOWTRAN building blocks; internal training and workshop documents; published papers about FLOWTRAN; articles about the history of the system; marketing documents; internal and external user's documentation; records of educational outreach projects in which the FLOWTRAN system were made available to universities; and miscellaneous memos and correspondence.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
